Award.AwardTitle: Probing the Central Engine of Active Galactic Nuclei
Award.AbstractNarration:
This program will explore the very inner structure of active galactic nuclei with the goals of (a) measuring the masses of the central black holes and (b) determining the structure and kinematics of the broad emission-line region. The main activities proposed are (1) reverberation-mapping studies that are designed to recover high fidelity velocity-delay maps of the broad-line region in several bright Seyfert 1 galaxies, and (2) continuing spectroscopic and imaging observations to calibrate the reverberation-based black hole mass scale. This will lead to a better determination of black hole masses in active galactic nuclei and will aid in understanding the relation between black hole masses and stellar velocity dispersions in galaxy bulges.

Broader impacts of the work include training of graduate students and a postdoc, work with a local science museum, teacher training, and public talks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The most important outcome of this on-going effort is the ability to determine the masses of supermassive black holes in active galactic nuclei (AGNs). Virtually all estimates of black hole masses in active galaxies, including distant quasars, are fundamentally based on the reverberation-based mass measurements, and study of the evolution of the demographics of black hole masses over the history of the Universe depends critically on reverberation mapping of these relatively nearby sources. Establishing the AGN black hole mass scale has three specific components: (1) direct measurements of black hole mass via reverberation mapping, (2) defining the relationship between broad-line region radius and AGN luminosity, and (3) anchoring the zero-point of the reverberation-based mass scale via relationships between black hole mass and host galaxy properties. Our group has made state-of-the-art contributions in each of these areas. We have also found, for the first time, statistically significant differences in the velocity-resolved response of the Hβ emission line in several galaxies, and are beginning to recover velocity-delay maps for both optical and ultraviolet emission lines. We have found that with the superb data we are now acquiring many of simplifying assumptions used in reverberation mapping break down, revealing interesting new properties of AGNs. We have also started to successfully resolve time lags between different continuum bands and have consequently determined the size and temperature structure of AGN accretion disks, showing that they are about three times larger than predicted by the simplest theories.

Broader Impact: This program involved several graduate students at multiple institutions who will receive training and hands-on experience as observers. One postdoctoral researcher and two graduate students at Ohio State have been trained to high levels of expertise in reverberation mapping. We have publicly disseminated our work through outreach talks and planetarium presentations.
